awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of technology to enable farmers with as little as one hectare of land to participate in global carbon and ecosystem services markets supporting their transition from traditional, degrading farming practices (e.g., monocrops and dependence on fertilizers, herbicides, and insecticides) to regenerative farming practices (e.g., agroforestry, low-till, and naturally nutritious, healthy soil) by offering companies the opportunity to meet their sustainability goals through the purchase of practice-based ecological assets. Although the market for these types of ecological assets has not yet been tested, the demand for carbon credits and other ecosystem services is growing rapidly. Current carbon credit origination costs are too expensive for small projects, only making financial sense beyond 1200 hectares in most cases. This technology will unlock the ability for the roughly 5 million small-holder farmers (farmers with only a few hectares of land) around the world to participate in these markets, scaling supply to meet the current demand and making meaningful progress toward climate goals.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of practice-based methodologies for verifying changes in ecological state using human-sensing (images and data recorded via smartphones), sky-sensing (satellite and drone images), remote-sensing (internet of things devices and sensors) and reputational-sensing (community accreditation of trustworthy projects). This project is developing a sustainable and scalable model for issuing practice-based ecological assets using decentralized, digital forms of measurement, reporting, and verification of ecosystem services. The technology is a platform to collect, synthesize, and share verifiable carbon sequestration data from international small-scale farmers. This approach reduces costs and increases climate action by leveraging often-overlooked small-holder farmers and technology readily available to them (more affordable, on their mobile phones, and via satellite imaging), to prove their conversion to regenerative practices. It also places data immutably on-chain as Proof-of-Impact (lower cost and more transparent than current methods).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Project Overview

Sunflower EcoTech, in partnership with NSF's iCorps program, conducted in-depth market research and developed an adaptive agroforestry methodology to enhance ecological sustainability. This project aimed to provide critical insights into the ecological assets market and create tools and strategies for diverse stakeholders.

Key Findings and Outcomes

1. Comprehensive Market Research on Ecological Assets

  • Value Propositions: Explored benefits for stakeholders such as risk mitigation for CIOs, brand enhancement for CMOs and CEOs, and supply chain resilience for commodity producers.
  • Insetting vs. Offsetting: Highlighted the preference for insetting, where companies integrate environmental projects into their operations to directly reduce their ecological footprint.
  • Biodiversity Credits: Identified the rise of biodiversity credits, which focus on preserving and enhancing biodiversity, offering a more comprehensive approach compared to traditional carbon credits.
  • Stakeholder Motivations: Identified three main groups:
    • Short-term: Philanthropists and speculators seeking immediate impacts or financial gains through speculated future value of ecological assets.
    • Medium-term: Commodity producers and insurance providers focusing on risk mitigation and climate resilience.
    • Long-term: Corporates and governments aiming for sustained environmental goals.

2. Development of Adaptive Agroforestry Stewardship Methodology Building on our market research, we developed a method to create eco credits tailored to short-term stakeholders like philanthropists and speculators. The Adaptive Agroforestry Stewardship Methodology is a framework designed to incentivize and reward regenerative agroforestry practices.

  • Climate Change Mitigation: Agroforestry systems can sequester significant amounts of CO2, helping mitigate climate change.
  • Biodiversity Conservation: These systems support higher biodiversity levels compared to conventional agricultural methods.
  • Soil Health Improvement: Agroforestry enhances soil organic matter and overall soil health.
  • Water and Air Quality: These practices help reduce water runoff and improve air quality.
  • Agroforestry Points (AP): We introduced a system to quantify and verify the ecological and social impact of agroforestry activities through digital Monitoring, Reporting, and Verification (dMRV) methods, ensuring transparency and accuracy in eco-credit issuance.

Conclusion

The ecological assets market is dynamic and evolving, characterized by complex stakeholder interactions and diverse value propositions. By aligning projects with the right stakeholders and emphasizing insetting practices, the market can enhance its credibility and attractiveness, driving meaningful environmental change.

______

Eco asset report: https://gamma.app/docs/Eco-Asset-Market-Research-2024-fwe8vjd7ajumen2?mode=doc
Agroforestry methodology: https://docs.google.com/document/d/15C44p7fubMFD0e2g7bK1hsHZfLHp55SkXVv1ciWU260/edit?usp=sharing

 

 


Last Modified: 09/06/2024
Modified by: Nathaniel Stern
por.por_txt_cntn:
Project Overview


Sunflower EcoTech, in partnership with NSF's iCorps program, conducted in-depth market research and developed an adaptive agroforestry methodology to enhance ecological sustainability. This project aimed to provide critical insights into the ecological assets market and create tools and strategies for diverse stakeholders.
Key Findings and Outcomes


1. Comprehensive Market Research on Ecological Assets

Value Propositions: Explored benefits for stakeholders such as risk mitigation for CIOs, brand enhancement for CMOs and CEOs, and supply chain resilience for commodity producers.
Insetting vs. Offsetting: Highlighted the preference for insetting, where companies integrate environmental projects into their operations to directly reduce their ecological footprint.
Biodiversity Credits: Identified the rise of biodiversity credits, which focus on preserving and enhancing biodiversity, offering a more comprehensive approach compared to traditional carbon credits.
Stakeholder Motivations: Identified three main groups: 

Short-term: Philanthropists and speculators seeking immediate impacts or financial gains through speculated future value of ecological assets.
Medium-term: Commodity producers and insurance providers focusing on risk mitigation and climate resilience.
Long-term: Corporates and governments aiming for sustained environmental goals.





2. Development of Adaptive Agroforestry Stewardship MethodologyBuilding on our market research, we developed a method to create eco credits tailored to short-term stakeholders like philanthropists and speculators. The Adaptive Agroforestry Stewardship Methodology is a framework designed to incentivize and reward regenerative agroforestry practices.

Climate Change Mitigation: Agroforestry systems can sequester significant amounts of CO2, helping mitigate climate change.
Biodiversity Conservation: These systems support higher biodiversity levels compared to conventional agricultural methods.
Soil Health Improvement: Agroforestry enhances soil organic matter and overall soil health.
Water and Air Quality: These practices help reduce water runoff and improve air quality.
Agroforestry Points (AP): We introduced a system to quantify and verify the ecological and social impact of agroforestry activities through digital Monitoring, Reporting, and Verification (dMRV) methods, ensuring transparency and accuracy in eco-credit issuance.

Conclusion


The ecological assets market is dynamic and evolving, characterized by complex stakeholder interactions and diverse value propositions. By aligning projects with the right stakeholders and emphasizing insetting practices, the market can enhance its credibility and attractiveness, driving meaningful environmental change.
